section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity you will need a set of five Two-Color Counters to serve as “lions,” a set of five Connecting Cubes to serve as “giraffes,” and a piece of yellow paper to represent the savannah.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read One Day on Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah, we saw many different animals, including lions and giraffes.
In this activity we will tell a number story about lions and giraffes that live on the African Savannah. We will count how many lions live there and how many giraffes live near them.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Have one child tell a story of how many lions are sleeping on the savannah today. Put those lions (counters) on the “savannah.” Then tell children, The giraffes live nearby. There are as many giraffes as there are lions! Challenge a child to place the same number of giraffes (counters) on the savannah with the lions.

Count Ask a child to point to each giraffe and count them one by one. Then ask the child to point to each lion and count one by one. Guide children to realize that these numbers are the same, even though two different items are being counted.
Repeat Continue with a new story of animals on the savannah, always keeping the numbers of lions and giraffes the same.

Talk About Same Did we have the same number of giraffes as lions? How do you know? Remind children that we can be certain the numbers of animals are the same by using a one-to-one comparison. Match up one lion counter with one giraffe counter to show the numbers are the same.

Start with only two lions and two giraffes, and increase the number as children become more proficient. Model the language for comparing two numbers. Two lions are over here while two giraffes are over there. There are two of each. That’s the same number of animals!
Invite children to use a third type of manipulative to compare three numbers and decide if they are the same.

Show the number of lions and giraffes requested on your fingers, and encourage children to do the same. Work with multilingual learners to create a number story together, reviewing vocabulary as needed.
Consider having children draw their own lions and giraffes, and cut them out as playing pieces for this activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need one set of 10 Connecting Cubes for each child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read One Day on Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah, we counted animals and discussed how we can resist impulses to be careful and follow rules.

In this activity, I am going to give you instructions about how to count and use your Connecting Cubes. But you should only follow those instructions when I say “Simon says.” You will have to stop and think before you act!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Simon Says Start with a pile of 10 cubes in front of each child. As “Simon,” direct children to count and connect their cubes. Say: Simon says, count out four blocks. Guide children to move four blocks from their pile and count them one at a time. Simon says, connect two cubes together. Guide children to connect two of their cubes.

Simon Doesn’t Say When children are comfortable with your directions, say, Count two cubes. Pause to see whether children have followed this instruction or not, and discuss. Ask, Is it difficult to stop and think before following the instructions?
Repeat Continue the activity, beginning only some instructions with “Simon says.” Pause for a moment to reflect with children after each time “Simon” doesn’t give the instruction.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How do you think the cub felt as he stopped to think before leaving the den? How did it feel when you had to stop and think before using your cubes?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Have children begin the game with five Connecting Cubes, or use your own set of cubes to count along with children as they play. Model giving an instruction without “Simon says,” and stop to think aloud.
Give children two-step instructions. For example: Simon says, count out three cubes and then connect them. Continue to add complexity as you repeat the activity.
Explain that “Simon” isn’t a real person, only a name that is used in this popular American game. Keep “Simon’s” instructions simple, and model completing instructions as needed.

Instead of having children use manipulatives, consider making the activity more active. For example: Simon says jump three times. Simon says march in place four times. Stretch your hands in the air two times!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, give each child a handful of Pattern Blocks.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read One Day on Our Blue Planet … in the Savannah, we described where animals live.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the words above and under. Use above and under Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, you will use Pattern Blocks to make a picture. Then, we will describe where each block is using above, under, and a few other location words.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Create Have each child use their Pattern Blocks to create a picture. Encourage children to make their picture however they would like and to be creative!

Ask Guide children to describe where specific Pattern Blocks are in their picture. For example: I see you have two rectangles below your square. Below is another word for under. What shape do you have under your triangle?

Turn and Talk Have children turn and talk with a partner about where in their picture they chose to place their blocks. Encourage them to use the position words “above,” “under,” “below,” “over,” and “next to,” helping to define new words as needed.

Talk About Location Talk with children about why location words are important. Give a vague direction such as “Pick up the book.” Explain that they cannot complete that task without more information. Saying, “Get the red book that is above the cubbies” is much more informative.

Limit the Pattern Blocks to three or four shapes, and identify them by color rather than shape. For example: I see two yellow shapes above your red shape. How many green shapes are next to this shape?

Hold up a manila folder as a “curtain.” Use your own set of Pattern Blocks “behind the curtain” to create a picture. Use position words to tell children where to place blocks to create the same image. When finished, lift the “curtain” to see if the children’s pictures match yours.
Begin the activity by reviewing the words above and under. Encourage children to use hand gestures for above and under as they say the words to reinforce their meaning.
Instead of using Pattern Blocks, ask children to draw a picture. Use location words to ask about where certain features of their picture are located.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read At the Pond, we saw many different animals that have homes there. Some have homes above the ground, and some have homes under the ground or underwater.
In this activity we will look at pictures of different animals in their homes. We will sort the animals by whether their homes are above the ground, under the ground, or underwater.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one Activity Card. Guide children to use location words to say whether the image is above the ground, under the ground, or underwater.

Discuss Ask children to explain how they know where the animal’s home is. Then, challenge them to imagine what it would be like to live in that home. Imagine you are a deer. What do you think it would be like to live in the forest? What would you do? What would you smell or see?
Repeat Continue the activity using the next card. Guide children to make three piles of cards, sorting by location: above ground, under ground, or underwater.

Talk About the Pond Connect the animals on the cards to the animals on the Big Chart of Big Ideas. Invite children to come up to the chart and point to each animal included in the activity. Ask, What are homes under the ground like? What makes them different from homes above the ground or underwater?

Some children may be unsure about where an animal lives because they are not familiar with the animals. Discuss how some animals, like rabbits, have their homes underground, but often come above ground to play or find food.
Challenge children to use more and varied location words to describe what they see in each picture. For example: This deer is standing next to her baby. They are standing below the trees.

Invite children to use hand motions for above, under, and underwater. You may also draw pictures to represent above ground, below ground, and underwater to aid children’s visualization of each concept.
Encourage children to pretend to be the animal on each card. Have them dig, jump, fly, or swim to show how the animal gets to its home.
